abstract.text: A view controller that displays content from a player and presents a native user interface to control playback.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A player view controller makes it simple to add media playback capabilities to your app that match the styling and features of the native system players. Using this object also means that your app automatically adopts the new features and styling of future operating system releases.
The framework doesn’t support subclassing

AirPlay lets users stream media to Apple TV, HomePod, and AirPlay 2-compatible speakers and smart TVs. A player view controller supports AirPlay automatically, but you need to configure your app to enable it. See
for more information about configuring your app for background playback.

provides Picture in Picture (PiP) playback in iOS, tvOS, and macOS. PiP playback lets users minimize the video player to a small floating window so they can perform other activities in the primary app or in another app.

in tvOS brings advanced Siri Remote control features to your app. This support lets users play and navigate your content, and access supporting features like subtitles and alternate audio tracks. This object also provides support for using Siri Remote voice commands, such as “Skip ahead 15 seconds” and “What did they say?”, to control playback of your content.
AVKit for tvOS extends the features of
and
to provide additional ways to navigate and present content. Features unique to the tvOS player user interface include:

Navigation Marker Groups. A group of navigation markers that allow a viewer to jump between significant events in the media timeline. The most common type of navigation marker group is a chapter list, but you can also create additional or alternative means of navigation — for example, to allow the user to quickly jump between key moments in a recorded sporting event. The player view controller lets the user choose between multiple marker groups for navigating through the media timeline.
Use the
class to create and describe navigation markers, then use the
property to associate marker groups with the current
object.

Interstitial Content. Some content might not relate to the main content that your app presents, or might have different presentation requirements. For example, you might not allow the user to skip over advertisements when scrubbing through the playback timeline, or to skip mandatory legal notices.
Use the
class to describe interstitial content, and the
property to associate those time ranges with the current
object.

Content Proposals. When presenting serialized content, like a TV show, you often want to propose additional content for the viewer to watch when the current episode ends. It’s straightforward to add this functionality to your app using content proposals.
Use the
class to describe the proposed content, and set it as the
property of the current
object. You can implement the methods of the player view controller’s
object to prepare to present a content proposal, and perform actions in response to the viewer accepting, rejecting, or deferring the proposal.

abstract.text: Create user interfaces for media playback, complete with transport controls, chapter navigation, picture-in-picture support, and display of subtitles and closed captions.
An object that describes a user interaction with a system hardware button.
An object that registers handlers to respond to capture events from system hardware buttons.
An object that describes the content to propose playing after the current item finishes.
A time range in an audiovisual presentation for content with an interstitial designation, such as advertisements or legal notices.
A set of markers for navigating playback of an audiovisual presentation.
An object that represents a user-selectable playback speed in a playback user interface.
A view controller that displays content from a player and presents a native user interface to control playback.
An array of language codes that restrict the set of subtitle languages available to the user.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player allows Picture in Picture playback.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to perform video frame analysis.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view controller automatically sets the screen’s display criteria to match that of the currently playing asset.
Presents the system trimming interface controls inside the player view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the current media supports trimming.
A Boolean value that indicates whether Picture in Picture starts automatically when transitioning to the background when the view controller presents its content inline.
A view that displays between the video content and the playback controls.
The view controller responsible for the presentation of content proposals.
An array of action controls to present contextually during playback.
A view the system shows adjacent to the contextual actions that’s suitable for showing related information.
An image to show alongside the contextual actions.
A view controller that provides client-specific content and controls alongside system-provided information and settings panels.
An array of view controllers to display as content tabs in the player user interface.
A view controller that presents custom content over the player view.
The delegate object for the player view controller.
A Boolean value that determines whether the player automatically displays in full screen when the user taps the play button.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player exits full-screen mode when playback ends.
The experience controller for this view controller.
The group experience coordinator for this view controller.
An array of actions to present in the Info content view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player item’s first video frame is ready for display.
A Boolean value that indicates whether backward-skipping is available.
A Boolean value that indicates whether forward-skipping is available.
The pixel buffer attributes of the video frames the view controller presents.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player presents video metadata, navigation markers, and playback settings views when the user requests them.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player shows the transport bar and related controls.
The player object that provides the media content for the view controller to display.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the user can disable the display of subtitles.
A Boolean value that determines whether the player allows the user to skip media content.
A Boolean value that indicates whether to permit playback of 2D video content only.
Selects a specified playback speed.
The currently selected playback speed.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player view controller shows playback controls.
A Boolean value that determines whether the player view displays timecodes, if available.
The behavior that skipping gestures perform.
A list of user-selectable playback speeds to show in the playback speed control.
An action that enables the visual lookup interface.
An array of actions and menus to display with the default player controls.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the player user interface shows the title view above the scrubber.
A layout guide that represents an area that fixed-position playback controls don’t obscure when visible.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view controller updates Now Playing information.
The size and position of the video image within the bounds of the view controller’s view.
The types of analysis a player view controller performs on a paused video frame.
A string that specifies how the video displays within the bounds of the view controller’s view.
A protocol that defines the methods to implement to respond to player view controller events.
Constants that represent the player view controller’s skipping behavior.
Constants that define the types of analysis a player view controller may perform on a paused video frame.
Add controls to your custom player user interface to invoke Picture in Picture (PiP) playback.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Adopting Picture in Picture in a Custom Player

abstract.text: Add Picture in Picture (PiP) playback to your app using a player view controller.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Adopting Picture in Picture in a Standard Player

abstract.text: Provide an optimized viewing experience for watching 3D video content.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Adopting the system player interface in visionOS

abstract.text: Adopt the latest features of the redesigned tvOS player user interface to provide a more streamlined way to watch your content.
Play media full screen, embedded inline, or in a floating Picture in Picture (PiP) window using a player view controller.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Playing video content in a standard user interface

abstract.text: Display standard controls in your app to edit the timeline of the currently playing media.

doc://com.apple.avkit/documentation/AVKi.title: Trimming and exporting media in visionOS

abstract.text: Present additional content alongside your main media presentation using HTTP Live Streaming support.
An object that models the timing and presentation state of an asset during playback.
An array of time ranges that identify interstitial content.
The time marker groups that provide ways to navigate the player item’s content.
The item proposed to follow the current content.
Configure apps to enable standard media playback behavior.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Configuring your app for media playback

abstract.text: An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
